text: Shortly after Saul had died, David returned from defeating the Amalekites and remained in Ziklag for two days.
speaker: Narrator

text: The next day, a man escaped from Saul’s camp! With torn clothes and dirty hair, he approached David, fell to the ground, and bowed down to him.
speaker: Narrator

text:
David asked him, “Where did you come from?
He answered him, “I just escaped from Israel’s encampment.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
David continued questioning him, “How did things go? Please tell me!”
He replied, “The army has fled the battlefield, many of the army are wounded or have died, and Saul and his son Jonathan are also dead.”
speaker: Narrator

text: David asked the young man who related the story, “How do you know that Saul and his son Jonathan are dead?”
speaker: Narrator

text: The young man who had been relating the story answered, “I happened to be on Mount Gilboa and there was Saul, leaning on his spear! Meanwhile, the chariots and horsemen were rapidly drawing near.
speaker: Narrator

text: Saul glanced behind him, saw me, and called out to me, so I replied, ‘Here I am!’
speaker: Narrator

text: He asked me, ‘Who are you?’ So I answered him, ‘I’m an Amalekite!’
speaker: Narrator

text: He begged me, ‘Please—come stand here next to me and kill me, because I’m still alive.’
speaker: Narrator

text: So I stood next to him and killed him, because I knew that he wouldn’t live after he had fallen. I took the crown that had been on his head, along with the bracelet that had been on his arm, and I have brought them to your majesty.”
speaker: Narrator

text: On hearing this, David grabbed his clothes and tore them, as did all the men who were attending to him.
speaker: Narrator

text: They mourned and wept, and then decided to fast until dusk for Saul, for his son Jonathan, for the army of the Lord, and for the house of Israel, because they had fallen in battle.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Meanwhile, David asked the young man who had told him the story, “Where are you from?”
He answered, “I’m an Amalekite, the son of a foreign man.”
speaker: Narrator

text: At this David asked him, “How is it that you weren’t afraid to raise your hand to strike the Lord’s anointed?”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then David called out to one of his young men and ordered him, “Go up to him and cut him down!” So he attacked him and killed him.
speaker: Narrator

text: David told him, “Your blood is on your own head, because your own words testified against you! After all, you said, ‘I myself have killed the Lord’s anointed!’”
speaker: Narrator

text: So David intoned this song of lament about Saul and his son Jonathan,
speaker: Narrator

text: and he gave orders to teach the descendants of Judah the art of warfare, as is recorded in the Book of Jashar:
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Your beauty, Israel, lies slain on your high places!
    O, how the valiant have fallen!
speaker: Narrator

text:
Don’t make it known in Gath!
    Don’t declare it in the avenues of Ashkelon!
Otherwise, the daughters of Philistia will rejoice;
    and the daughters of the uncircumcised will triumph.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Mountains of Gilboa,
    let no dew or rain fall on you,
        and may none of your fields be filled with plenty,
because in that place the shield of the valiant ones was defiled,
    the shield of Saul without an anointing with oil.
speaker: Narrator

text:
From the blood of the slain,
    from the blood of the valiant,
Jonathan’s bow would not retreat
    nor would Saul’s sword return empty.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Saul and Jonathan, loved and handsome in life,
    in death were not separated.
Swifter than eagles they were,
    and more valiant than lions.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Daughters of Israel, weep over Saul!
    He clothed you in scarlet luxury
        and decorated your garments with gold.
speaker: Narrator

text:
How have the valiant fallen in the tumult of battle!
    Jonathan lies slain on your high places.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I am in distress for you, my brother Jonathan.
    You have been most kind to me.
Your love for me was extraordinary—
    beyond love from women.
speaker: Narrator

text:
How the valiant have fallen!
    How the weapons of war are destroyed!”
speaker: Narrator

text:
Some time later, David inquired of the Lord to ask, “Am I to move to any one of the cities of Judah?”
The Lord told him, “Go.”
So David asked, “To which one?”
He replied, “To Hebron.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So David went there, along with his two wives Ahinoam from Jezreel and Abigail, widow of Nabal from Carmel.
speaker: Narrator

text: David brought his army with him, each soldier accompanied by his household, and they settled in the cities of Hebron.
speaker: Narrator

text:
After this, the army of Judah arrived, and they anointed David king over the house of Judah.
There they informed David, “The men of Jabesh-gilead buried Saul.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So David sent messengers to the people of Jabesh-gilead and told them, “May the Lord bless you, because you showed gracious love like this to your lord Saul by burying him.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now may the Lord reward you with gracious love, as well as faithfulness, to you, too! And I will also reward you because you did this good thing.
speaker: Narrator

text: So strengthen yourselves, and be valiant in heart, because your lord Saul has died, and the household of Judah has anointed me to be king over them.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Meanwhile, Ner’s son Abner, the commander of Saul’s army, had taken Saul’s son Ish-bosheth and brought him to Mahanaim.
speaker: Narrator

text: He installed him as king over Gilead, the Ashurites, Jezreel, Ephraim, Benjamin, and all of the rest of Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: Ish-bosheth began to reign over Israel at the age of 40 years, and he reigned for two years, even though Judah’s lineage followed David.
speaker: Narrator

text: The period of David’s kingship in Hebron lasted seven years and six months.
speaker: Narrator

text: Ner’s son Abner and the servants of Saul’s son Ish-bosheth set out from Mahanaim for Gibeon.
speaker: Narrator

text: Zeruiah’s son Joab and some of David’s staff went out to meet them at the pool of Gibeon. One side encamped on one side of the pool while the other encamped on the other side of the pool.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Abner told Joab, “Let’s have the young men get up and fight in our presence.”
Joab replied, “Let them come.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So they got up and twelve were counted to represent Benjamin and Saul’s son Ish-bosheth and twelve to represent members of David’s staff.
speaker: Narrator

text: Each man grabbed his opponent by the head, plunged his sword into his opponent’s side, and then they both fell together. That’s why the place at Gibeon was named The Field of Swords.
speaker: Narrator

text: The battle was very violent that day, with Abner and the men of Israel being defeated in the presence of David’s servants.
speaker: Narrator

text: Zeruiah’s three sons Joab, Abishai, and Asahel were there. As a runner, Asahel was fast, like one of the wild gazelles.
speaker: Narrator

text: So Asahel ran straight after Abner, following him.
speaker: Narrator

text:
When Abner looked behind him, he said, “Is that you, Asahel?”
He answered, “I am.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Abner told him, “Go off to your right or left after one of the young men and grab some war spoils.” But Asahel would not stop following him,
speaker: Narrator

text: so Abner told Asahel again, “Stop following me. Why should I strike you down? How could I show my face to your brother Joab?”
speaker: Narrator

text: But Asahel refused to turn away, so Abner struck Asahel in the abdomen with the butt end of his spear, and the spear protruded through his back. He collapsed to the ground and died where he fell. Everyone gathered round the place where Asahel had collapsed and died, and stood still there.
speaker: Narrator

text: Meanwhile, Joab and Abishai continued to chase Abner. At dusk, as they approached the hill of Ammah that is located near Giah on the way to the Gibeon desert,
speaker: Narrator

text: the descendants of Benjamin rallied around Abner, forming a single military force. They took their stand on top of the hill.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Abner called out to Joab, “Must the battle sword keep on devouring forever? Don’t you realize that the end result is bitterness? How long will it take for you to order your army to stop pursuing their own relatives?”
speaker: Narrator

text: Joab answered, “As God lives, if you hadn’t spoken up, by morning my army would have broken off their pursuit of their own relatives.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Joab sounded his battle trumpet, his entire army stopped pursuing Israel any longer, and they quit fighting.
speaker: Narrator

text: Abner and his army traveled through the Arabah by night, crossed the Jordan, and arrived at Mahanaim after marching all morning.
speaker: Narrator

text: Joab returned from his pursuit of Abner, and when he had mustered his entire army, nineteen of David’s soldiers were missing besides Asahel.
speaker: Narrator

text: Meanwhile, other soldiers of David had killed 360 of Abner’s men from the tribe of Benjamin.
speaker: Narrator

text: They retrieved Asahel’s body and buried him in his father’s tomb at Bethlehem. Then Joab and his men marched all night until daybreak and arrived back in Hebron.
speaker: Narrator

text: After this, a state of protracted war existed between Saul’s dynasty and David’s dynasty, and the dynasty of David continued to grow and become strong while the dynasty of Saul continued to grow weaker.
speaker: Narrator

text: During this time, sons were born to David while he was living in Hebron. His firstborn was Amnon by Ahinoam from Jezreel,
speaker: Narrator

text: his second was Chileab by Abigail, widow of Nabal from Carmel, his third was Absalom by Maacah, daughter of King Talmai from Geshur,
speaker: Narrator

text: his fourth was Adonijah by Haggith, his fifth was Shephatiah by Abital,
speaker: Narrator

text: and his sixth was Ithream by David’s wife Eglah. They were all born to David in Hebron.
speaker: Narrator

text: While war continued between the dynasties of Saul and David, Abner was growing in influence within the dynasty of Saul.
speaker: Narrator

text: Meanwhile, Saul had a mistress named Rizpah, who was the daughter of Aiah. Ish-bosheth asked Abner, “Why did you have sex with my father’s mistress?”
speaker: Narrator

text: What Ish-bosheth said made Abner furious, so he replied, “A dog’s head for Judah—is that what I am? Up until today I’ve kept on showing loyalty to your father Saul’s dynasty, to his relatives and friends, and I haven’t turned you over to David, but you’re charging me today with moral guilt regarding this woman!
speaker: Narrator

text: Therefore may God do to me—and more also!—just as the Lord has promised to David, since I’m doing this for him:
speaker: Narrator

text: I will take away the kingdom from the dynasty of Saul by making the throne of David firm over Israel and Judah—from Dan to Beer-sheba!”
speaker: Narrator

text: Ish-bosheth couldn’t say another word in response to Abner, because he was terrified of him.
speaker: Narrator

text: So Abner sent messengers to David at Hebron to ask him, “Who owns this land? Cut a deal with me, and look!—I’ll lend my hand in bringing all of Israel over to you!”
speaker: Narrator

text: David replied, “Sounds good to me! I’ll cut a deal with you under one condition: you’re not to show yourself in my presence unless you bring Saul’s daughter with you when you come to see me.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then David sent a delegation to Saul’s son Ish-bosheth to say, “Give me my wife Michal, to whom I was engaged with a dowry of 100 Philistine foreskins.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Ish-bosheth ordered that she be taken away from her husband, Laish’s son Paltiel.
speaker: Narrator

text: Her husband accompanied her, crying as he followed after her all the way to Bahurim, where Abner told him, “Leave! Go back!” So he went back.
speaker: Narrator

text: Later, Abner had a talk with the elders of Israel. He said, “In the past you were looking to see David made king over you.
speaker: Narrator

text:
So do it, then! Because the Lord has said this about David:
‘Through my servant David I will save my people Israel
    from the control of the Philistines
        and from all of their enemies.’”
speaker: Narrator

text: Abner also addressed the tribe of Benjamin. Furthermore, with David’s permission, Abner said anything that seemed like it would be good for Israel and for the entire tribe of Benjamin.
speaker: Narrator

text: Afterwards, Abner brought 20 soldiers to David at Hebron, and David threw a party for Abner and the men who were with him.
speaker: Narrator

text: So Abner told David, “Give me permission to go out and rally all of Israel to your majesty the king so they can enter into a formal agreement with you to reign over everything that your heart desires.” So David sent Abner off, and he went away in peace.
speaker: Narrator

text: Right about then, David’s servants returned from a raid, bringing plenty of war booty with them, but Abner wasn’t in Hebron with David, since David had sent him away and Abner had left in peace.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Joab returned with his entire army, Joab was informed, “Ner’s son Abner visited the king, and he has dismissed him. He has left in peace.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Joab approached the king and asked him, “What have you done? Look, Abner came to you! What’s this? You sent him away? He’s long gone now!
speaker: Narrator

text: You know Ner’s son Abner came to mislead you, to learn your troop movements, and to learn everything you’re doing!”
speaker: Narrator

text: As soon as Joab left David, Joab sent messengers after Abner, and they brought him back from the cistern at Sirah, but David was not aware of this.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Abner returned to Hebron, Joab brought him aside within the gateway to talk to him alone and then stabbed him in the abdomen. So he died for shedding the blood of Joab’s brother Asahel.
speaker: Narrator

text: Later on, David found out about it and proclaimed, “Let me and my kingdom remain guiltless forever in the Lord’s presence for the death of Ner’s son Abner.
speaker: Narrator

text: May judgment rest on Joab’s head and on his father’s entire household. May Joab’s dynasty never be without one who has a discharge, who is a leper, who walks with a cane, who commits suicide, or who lacks food!”
speaker: Narrator

text: He said this because Joab and his brother Abishai murdered Abner after he had killed their brother Asahel in the battle at Gibeon.
speaker: Narrator

text: David ordered Joab and all the people who were with him, “Tear your clothes, put on sackcloth, and mourn for Abner.” King David walked behind the funeral procession,
speaker: Narrator

text: and they buried Abner at Hebron. The king wept loudly at Abner’s grave, and all the people wept, too.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The king composed this mourning song for Abner:
“Should Abner’s death be like a fool’s?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Your hands were not bound,
        nor were your feet in irons.
As one falls before the wicked,
    you have fallen.”
Then all the people cried again because of him.
speaker: Narrator

text: Everyone tried to persuade David to have a meal while there was still daylight, but David took an oath by saying, “May God to do like this to me and more, if I taste bread or anything else before the sun sets!”
speaker: Narrator

text: Everybody took note of this and was very pleased, just as everything else the king did pleased everyone.
speaker: Narrator

text: As a result, the entire army and all of Israel understood that day that the king had nothing to do with the murder of Ner’s son Abner.
speaker: Narrator

text: The king reminded his staff, “Don’t you know that a prince and a great man has fallen today in Israel?
speaker: Narrator

text: Today, even though I’m anointed as king, I’m weak. These men, sons of Zeruiah, are too difficult for me. May the Lord repay the one who acts wickedly in accordance with his wickedness!”
speaker: Narrator

text: When Saul’s son heard that Abner had died in Hebron, his courage failed and all of Israel was disturbed.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now Saul’s son had two officers in charge of some raiding parties. One was named Baanah and the other was named Rechab. They were sons of Rimmon, a descendant of Benjamin from Beeroth, which was considered to belong to the tribe of Benjamin.
speaker: Narrator

text: (The residents of Beeroth had evacuated to Gittaim and live there as resident aliens to this day.)
speaker: Narrator

text: Meanwhile, Saul’s son Jonathan had a son whose feet were crippled. When he was five years old, news had arrived about Saul and Jonathan from Jezreel, and his nurse picked him up to flee, but in her hurry to leave, he happened to fall and became lame. His name was Mephibosheth.
speaker: Narrator

text: Rechab and Baanah, the sons of Rimmon the Beerothite, left and arrived during the hottest part of the day at the home of Ish-bosheth while he was taking a noon day nap.
speaker: Narrator

text: They entered the house as though they intended to obtain some grain and stabbed him in the abdomen. Then Rechab and his brother Baanah escaped.
speaker: Narrator

text: While they were in the house, they struck him, killed him, and cut off his head while he was lying on his bed in his bedroom. They took his head, and traveled all night along the Arabah road.
speaker: Narrator

text: They brought Ish-bosheth’s head to David at Hebron and told the king, “Look! Here’s the head of your enemy Ish-bosheth, Saul’s son, who sought your life. Today the Lord has given your majesty the king vengeance on Saul and his descendants.”
speaker: Narrator

text: David responded to Rechab and his brother Baanah, the sons of Rimmon the Beerothite: “As the Lord lives, who has saved my life in every adversity,
speaker: Narrator

text: when the man who told me ‘Look! Saul is dead!’ thought he was bringing me good news, I arrested him and had him killed at Ziklag as the reward I gave him for his news.
speaker: Narrator

text: How much worse will it be, then, when evil men kill an innocent man on his own bed in his own house! Shouldn’t I avenge his blood—which you are responsible for shedding—by removing you from the earth?”
speaker: Narrator

text: So David commanded his personal guards, and they killed Rechab and Baanah, cut off their hands and feet, and hung up their bodies beside the pool at Hebron. They took Ish-bosheth’s head and buried it in Abner’s tomb at Hebron.
speaker: Narrator

text: After this, all of the tribes of Israel assembled with David at Hebron and declared, “Look, we’re your own flesh and blood!
speaker: Narrator

text: Even back when Saul was our king, it was you who kept on leading Israel out to battle and bringing them back again. The Lord told you, ‘You yourself will shepherd my people Israel and serve as Commander-in-Chief over Israel.’”
speaker: Narrator

text: So all the elders of Israel approached the king at Hebron, where King David entered into a covenant with them in the presence of the Lord. Then they anointed David to be king over Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: David began to reign when he was 30 years old, and he reigned 40 years.
speaker: Narrator

text: He reigned over Judah for seven years and six months in Hebron, and he reigned over all of Israel including Judah for 33 years in Jerusalem.
speaker: Narrator

text: Later, the king and his army marched on Jerusalem against the Jebusites, who were inhabiting the territory at that time and who had told David, “You’re not coming in here! Even the blind and the lame could turn you away!” because they were thinking “David can’t come here.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Even so, David captured the stronghold of Zion, which is now known as the City of David.
speaker: Narrator

text:
At that time, David had said, “Whoever intends to attack the Jebusites will have to climb up the water shaft to attack the lame and blind, who hate David.”
Therefore they say, “The blind and lame are never to come into the house.”
speaker: Narrator

text: David occupied the fortress, naming it the City of David. He built up the surroundings from the terrace ramparts inward.
speaker: Narrator

text: David became more and more esteemed because the Lord God of the Heavenly Armies was with him.
speaker: Narrator

text: Later, King Hiram of Tyre sent a delegation to David, accompanied by cedar logs, carpenters, and stone masons. They built a palace for David.
speaker: Narrator

text: So David concluded that the Lord had established him as king over Israel and that he had exalted his kingdom in order to benefit his people Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: But after arriving in Jerusalem after leaving Hebron, David took more wives and mistresses, and more sons and daughters were born to David.
speaker: Narrator

text: These are the names of those who were born to him in Jerusalem: Shammua, Shobab, Nathan, Solomon,
speaker: Narrator

text: Ibhar, Elishua, Nepheg, Japhia,
speaker: Narrator

text: Elishama, Eliada, and Eliphelet.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the Philistines eventually learned that Israel had anointed David to be king over Israel, they marched out in search of him. But David heard about it and retreated to his stronghold.
speaker: Narrator

text: Meanwhile, the Philistines arrived and encamped in the Rephaim Valley,
speaker: Narrator

text:
so David asked the Lord, “Am I to go attack the Philistines? Will you give me victory over them?”
“Go get them,” the Lord replied to David, “because I’m going to put the Philistines right into your hand!”
speaker: Narrator

text: So David went to Baal-perazim and defeated them there. He called the place Baal-perazim, because he said, “Like a bursting flood, the Lord has jumped out in front of me to fight my enemies.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The Philistines abandoned their idols there, and David and his army carried them off.
speaker: Narrator

text: Later, the Philistines once again marched out and encamped in the Rephaim Valley.
speaker: Narrator

text: When David asked the Lord about it, he said, “Don’t attack them directly. Instead, go around to the rear and attack them opposite those balsam trees.
speaker: Narrator

text: When you hear the sound of marching coming from the tops of the balsam trees, then be sure to act quickly, since the Lord will have gone out ahead of you to cut down the Philistine army.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So David did exactly what the Lord ordered him to do, and he struck down the Philistines from Geba to Gezer.
speaker: Narrator

text: After this, David gathered together again 30,000 men from all of the choicest men of Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then David and all the people with him set out from Baal-judah to bring up from there the Ark of God, who is called the Name, the name of the Lord of the Heavenly Armies, and who is enthroned on the cherubim.
speaker: Narrator

text: They mounted the Ark of God on a new cart and brought it from Abinadab’s home in Gibeah, with Abinadab’s sons Uzzah and Ahio driving the new cart.
speaker: Narrator

text: As they left Abinadab’s house in Gibeah accompanied by the Ark of God, Ahio was walking ahead of the ark.
speaker: Narrator

text: David and the entire assembly of Israel were dancing in the presence of the Lord with all of their strength, accompanied by all sorts of wood instruments, harps, tambourines, castanets, and cymbals.
speaker: Narrator

text: When they arrived at Nacon’s threshing floor, Uzzah reached out and grabbed the Ark of God because the oxen had stumbled.
speaker: Narrator

text: Just then, the anger of the Lord blazed against Uzzah, and God struck him down right there because of his failure, and he died there beside the Ark of God.
speaker: Narrator

text: David flew into a rage because the Lord had killed Uzzah. That’s why that place is called Perez-uzzah to this day.
speaker: Narrator

text: But David feared the Lord that day, and asked, “How can the Ark of God come to me?”
speaker: Narrator

text: As a result, David was unwilling to take the ark of the Lord into his care in the City of David. Instead, David left it at the home of Obed-edom the Gittite.
speaker: Narrator

text: So the ark of the Lord remained for three months in the household of Obed-edom the Gittite while the Lord blessed Obed-edom and his entire household.
speaker: Narrator

text: Later on, David was informed, “The Lord has blessed the home of Obed-edom and everything he has since he’s in possession of the Ark of God.” So David went out joyfully and brought up the Ark of God to the City of David from Obed-edom’s home.
speaker: Narrator

text: After those who were carrying the ark of the Lord had taken six steps, he sacrificed oxen and fattened animals,
speaker: Narrator

text: dancing in front of the Lord with all of his strength and wearing a linen ephod.
speaker: Narrator

text: So David and the entire assembly of Israel brought up the ark of the Lord with shouting and trumpet blasts.
speaker: Narrator

text: As the ark of the Lord was coming into the City of David, Saul’s daughter Michal was peering out a window, watching King David jumping and dancing in the Lord’s presence, and she despised him in her heart.
speaker: Narrator

text: They brought in the ark of the Lord, set it in place inside the tent that David had erected for it, and David sacrificed burnt offerings and peace offerings in the presence of the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: After David had finished sacrificing the burnt offerings and peace offerings, he blessed the people in the name of the Lord of the Heavenly Armies
speaker: Narrator

text: and distributed to all the people—the entire multitude of Israel, including both men and women—a cake made of bread, one made of dates, and one made of raisins to each one. Then all the people left, each headed for home.
speaker: Narrator

text: When David returned to bless his household, Saul’s daughter Michal came out to meet him and called out, “How the king of Israel honored himself today by undressing himself right in front of his women staff members, just like any pervert would dare to expose himself!”
speaker: Narrator

text: But David replied to Michal, “It was in front of the Lord, who appointed me to replace your father and his entire household by selecting me as Commander-in-Chief over Israel, the people of the Lord, that I danced in front of the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: I’m going to act more shamelessly than this, even to humbling myself in my own eyes. Now as to the women staff members about whom you have spoken, they are to hold me in honor!”
speaker: Narrator

text: And Saul’s daughter Michal bore no children from that day on until the day she died.
speaker: Narrator

text: After the king had settled down in his palace and the Lord had given him respite from all of his surrounding enemies,
speaker: Narrator

text: he told the prophet Nathan, “Look now, I’m living in a cedar palace, but the Ark of God resides behind a tent curtain.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Nathan replied to the king, “Go do everything you have in mind, because the Lord is with you.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But later that same night, this message came to Nathan from the Lord:
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Go tell my servant David, ‘This is what the Lord says: 
“‘“Are you going to build a house for me to inhabit?
speaker: Narrator

text: After all, I haven’t lived in a house since the day I brought up the Israelis from Egypt until now. Instead, I’ve moved around in a tent that served as my dwelling place.
speaker: Narrator

text: Wherever I moved among the Israelis, did I ever ask even one tribal leader of Israel whom I commanded to shepherd my people Israel, ‘Why haven’t you built me a cedar house?’
speaker: Narrator

text: “‘“Now therefore this is what you are to tell my servant David: ‘This is what the Lord of the Heavenly Armies says: “I took you from the pasture myself—from tending sheep—to become Commander-in-Chief over my people, that is, over Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: “‘“Furthermore, I have remained with you everywhere you have gone, annihilating all your enemies right in front of you. I will make a great reputation for you, like the reputation of great ones who have lived on earth.
speaker: Narrator

text: I will establish a homeland for my people—for Israel—planting them so they may live in a secure location where they will never be disturbed anymore. Wicked people will no longer afflict them, as happened in the past
speaker: Narrator

text:

speaker: Narrator

speaker: Narrator

text: Just as he finished his comments, the king’s sons arrived, crying loudly. At this, with tears overflowing, the king and his entire staff wept bitterly.
speaker: Narrator

text: Absalom continued to flee, eventually going to Ammihud’s son King Talmai of Geshur, while King David continued to mourn for his son every day.
speaker: Narrator

text: After fleeing to Geshur, Absalom remained there for three years.
speaker: Narrator

text: Meanwhile, King David longed to visit Absalom, since he was moved to compassion over Amnon’s death.
speaker: Narrator

text: Meanwhile, Zeruiah’s son Joab knew that the king’s attention was focused on Absalom,
speaker: Narrator

text: so he sent messengers to Tekoa to bring a wise woman from there. He told her, “Please play the role of a mourner, wear the clothes of a mourner, and refrain from using makeup. Act like a woman who’s been in mourning for the dead for many days.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then go to the king and speak to him like this…” Then Joab told her what to say.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the woman from Tekoa spoke to the king, she fell on her face to the ground, prostrating herself to address him, “Help, your majesty!”
speaker: Narrator

text:
The king asked her, “What’s your problem?”
“I’ve been a widowed woman ever since my husband died,” she answered.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Your humble servant used to have two sons, but they got into a fight out in the field. Because there was no one to keep them apart, one of them attacked the other and killed him.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now please pay attention closely! My whole family is attacking your humble servant! speaker: Narrator

text: Then the king replied to the woman, “Go home and I’ll issue a special order just for you.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But the woman from Tekoa told the king, “Your majesty, let any guilt for this be on me and on my ancestors’ household, and not on my king or his throne!”
speaker: Narrator

text: The king replied, “Bring anyone who talks to you about this to me, and he certainly won’t be bothering you anymore!”
speaker: Narrator

text:
Then she said, “Your majesty, please remember the Lord your God, so that blood avengers don’t do any more damage! Otherwise, they’ll destroy my son!”
So he promised, “As the Lord lives, not even a single hair from your son’s head will fall to the ground!”
speaker: Narrator

text:
At this, the woman responded, “Would your majesty the king please allow your humble servant to say one more thing?”
“Say it…” he replied.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Why, then,” the woman asked, “are you planning to act just like this against God’s people? Based on what your majesty has said, you’re acting like one who is guilty himself, because you’re not bringing back the one whom you’ve banished!
speaker: Narrator

text: After all, even though we all die, and we’re all like water being spilled on the ground that cannot be recovered, nevertheless God doesn’t take away life, but carries out his plans so as not to cast away permanently from him those who are presently estranged.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Now as to why I’ve come to speak with your majesty the king, it’s because the people have made me afraid, so your humble servant told herself, ‘I’ll go speak to the king, so perhaps the king will do what his humble servant has requested.
speaker: Narrator

text: Perhaps the king will listen and deliver his humble servant from the oppression of the man who intends to eliminate both me and my son from what God has apportioned to us!’
speaker: Narrator

text: “So your humble servant is saying, ‘Please, your majesty, let what the king has to say be of comfort, because just as the angel of God is, so also is your majesty the king to discern both good and evil. And may the Lord your God remain present with you.’”
speaker: Narrator

text:
In reply, the king asked the woman, “Please don’t conceal anything about which I’m going to be asking you now.”
So the woman replied, “Please, your majesty, let the king speak.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
Then the king asked, “Is Joab behind all of this with you?”
“As your soul lives, your majesty, the king,” the woman answered, “no one can divert anything left or right from what your majesty the king has spoken! As a matter of fact, it was your servant Joab! He was there, giving me precise orders about everything that your humble servant was to say. Your servant Joab did this,
speaker: Narrator

text: intending to change the outcome of this matter. Nevertheless, your majesty is wise, like the wisdom of the angel of God, to be aware of everything that’s going on throughout the earth.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the king addressed Joab, “Look! I’ll do this thing that you’ve requested. Go bring back the young man Absalom.”
speaker: Narrator

text: At this, Joab fell on his face to the ground, prostrating himself to bless the king, and then said, “Today your servant realizes that he’s found favor with you, your majesty, in that the king has acted on the request of his servant.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Joab got up, went to Geshur, and brought Absalom back to Jerusalem.
speaker: Narrator

text: Nevertheless, the king said, “Let him return to his own home and not show his face to me.” So Absalom returned to his own home and did not show his face to the king.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now throughout all of Israel no one was as handsome as Absalom or so highly praised, from the sole of his foot to the crown of his head there wasn’t a single thing wrong about him.
speaker: Narrator

text: Whenever he cut his hair —he cut it at the end of every year, because it grew thick on his head, which is why he cut it—his hair weighed in at 200 shekels measured by the royal standard.
speaker: Narrator

text: Absalom fathered three sons and one daughter, whom he named Tamar. She was a beautiful woman, both in form and appearance.
speaker: Narrator

text: Meanwhile, Absalom lived in Jerusalem for two years, but never saw the king’s face.
speaker: Narrator

text: After this, Absalom sent for Joab, intending to send him to the king, but Joab would not come. Absalom sent for him a second time, but he still would not come.
speaker: Narrator

text: So Absalom told his servants, “Observe that Joab’s grain field lies next to mine. He has barley planted there. Go set it on fire.” So Absalom’s servants set the field on fire.
speaker: Narrator

text: At this, Joab got up, went to Absalom’s home, and demanded of him, “Why did your servants set fire to my grain field?”
speaker: Narrator

text: In answer to Joab, Absalom replied, “Look, I sent for you, telling you ‘Come here so I can send you to the king to ask him “What’s the point in moving here from Geshur? I would have been better off to have remained there!”’ So let me see the king’s face, and if I’m guilty of anything, let him execute me!”
speaker: Narrator

text: So when Joab approached the king and told him what Absalom had said, he summoned Absalom, who then came to the king and fell to the ground on his face in front of him. Then the king kissed Absalom.
speaker: Narrator

text: Sometime later, Absalom acquired a chariot equipped with horses and recruited 50 men to accompany him.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then he would get up early, stand near the passageway to the palace gate, and when anyone arrived to file a legal complaint for a hearing before the king, Absalom would call to him and ask, “You’re from what city?” If he replied, “Your servant is from one of Israel’s tribes,”
speaker: Narrator

text: Absalom would respond, “Look, your claims are valid and defensible, but nobody will listen to you on behalf of the king.
speaker: Narrator

text: Who will appoint me to be a judge in the land? When anyone arrived to file a legal complaint or other cause, he could approach me for justice and I would settle it!”
speaker: Narrator

text: Furthermore, if a man approached him to bow down in front of him, he would put out his hand, grab him, and embrace him.
speaker: Narrator

text: By doing all of this to anyone who came to the king for a hearing, Absalom stole the loyalty of the men of Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: And so it was that forty years after Israel had demanded a king, Absalom asked the king, “Please let me go to Hebron so I can pay my vow that I made to the Lord,
speaker: Narrator

text: because when I was living at Geshur in Aram, your servant made this solemn promise: ‘If the Lord ever brings me back to Jerusalem, then I will serve the Lord.’”
speaker: Narrator

text: The king replied to him, “Go in peace!” So Absalom got up and left for Hebron.
speaker: Narrator

text: But Absalom sent agents throughout all of the tribes of Israel, telling them, “When you hear the sound of the battle trumpet, you’re to announce that Absalom is king in Hebron.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Meanwhile, 200 men left Jerusalem with Absalom. They had been invited to go along, but were innocent, not knowing anything about what was happening.
speaker: Narrator

text: Absalom also sent for Ahithophel the Gilonite, David’s counselor, to come from his home town of Giloh while Absalom was presenting the sacrificial offerings. And so the conspiracy widened, because the common people increasingly sided with Absalom.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then a messenger arrived to inform David, “The loyalties of the men of Israel have shifted to Absalom.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So David told all of his staff who were with him in Jerusalem, “Let’s get up and get out of here! Otherwise, none of us will escape from Absalom. Hurry, or he’ll overtake us quickly, bring disaster on all of us, and execute the inhabitants of the city!”
speaker: Narrator

text: “Look!” the king’s staff replied. “Your servants will do whatever the king chooses.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So the king left, taking his entire household with him except for ten mistresses, who were to keep the palace in order.
speaker: Narrator

text: The king left, along with all of his people with him, and they paused at the last house.
speaker: Narrator

text: All of his staff were going on ahead of him—that is, all of the special forces and mercenaries, all of the Gittites, and 600 men who had come to serve him from Gath, went on ahead of the king.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the king suggested to Ittai the Gittite, “Why should you have to go with us? Return and stay with the new king, since you’re a foreigner and exile. Stay where you want to stay.
speaker: Narrator

text: It seems only yesterday that you arrived, so should I make you wander around with us while I go wherever I can? Go back, and take your brothers with you. May gracious love and truth accompany you!”
speaker: Narrator

text: “As the Lord lives,” Ittai answered in reply, “and as your majesty the king lives, wherever your majesty my king may be—whether living or dying—that’s where your servant will be!”
speaker: Narrator

text: So David replied, “Come along, then!” So Ittai the Gittite went along also, accompanied by all of his men and all of his little ones.
speaker: Narrator

text: With all of the people in the territory crying loudly, everybody passed over the Kidron brook, along with the king. Then everyone headed out toward the road that leads to the wilderness.
speaker: Narrator

text: Meanwhile, Zadok showed up also, along with all of the descendants of Levi with him, carrying the Ark of the Covenant of God. They set down the Ark of God and Abiathar approached while all the people finished abandoning the city.
speaker: Narrator

text: The king told Zadok, “Take the Ark of God back to the city. If I’m shown favor in the Lord’s sight, then he’ll bring me back again and show me both it and the place where it rests.
speaker: Narrator

text: But if he should say something like ‘I’m not pleased with you,’ well then, here I am—let him do to me whatever seems right to him.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The king also asked Zadok the priest, “Aren’t you a seer, too? Go back to the city in comfort, along with your son Ahimaaz and Abiathar’s son Jonathan.
speaker: Narrator

text: Look! I’ll camp at the wilderness fords until you send word to inform me.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Zadok and Abiathar returned the Ark of God to Jerusalem and remained there.
speaker: Narrator

text: David then left, going up the Mount of Olives, crying as he went, with his head covered and his feet bare. All of the people who were with him covered their own heads and climbed up the Mount of Olives, crying as they went along.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Just then, someone told David, “Ahithophel is one of Absalom’s conspirators!”
So David prayed, “Lord, please turn Ahithophel’s counsel into foolishness.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Just as David was coming to the top of the Mount of Olives where God was being worshipped, there was Hushai the Archite to meet him, with his coat ripped and dust all over his head!
speaker: Narrator

text: David greeted him, “If you come along with me, you’ll be a burden to me.
speaker: Narrator

text: So go back to the city and tell Absalom, ‘I’ll be your servant, your majesty! Just as I served your father in the past, I can be your servant now.’ That way you can manipulate Ahithophel’s advice to my benefit.
speaker: Narrator

text: Won’t Zadok and Abiathar the priests be there with you? So whatever you hear from the king’s palace, you’re to report to Zadok and Abiathar the priests.
speaker: Narrator

text: Their two sons—Zadok’s son Ahimaaz and Abiathar’s son Jonathan—are with them there. You’ll be sending me everything that you hear through them.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So David’s friend Hushai went back to the city just as Absalom was arriving in Jerusalem.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now just as David happened to have passed the summit of the Mount of Olives, suddenly Mephibosheth’s servant Ziba met him, accompanied by a couple of saddled donkeys loaded with 200 loaves of bread, 100 clusters of raisins, 100 pieces of summer fruit, and a skin of wine!
speaker: Narrator

text:
The king asked Ziba, “What are those for?”
Ziba replied, “The donkeys are for the king’s household to ride, the bread and summer fruit are for your young men to eat, and the wine is for whoever wants to drink if they get weary in the wilderness.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
Then the king asked, “Where is your master’s son?”
“He’s staying in Jerusalem!” Ziba answered the king. “He’s saying ‘The nation of Israel will restore my father’s kingdom to me today!’”
speaker: Narrator

text:
So the king told Ziba, “Pay attention! Everything that belongs to Mephibosheth is now yours!”
In response Ziba said, “I’m submitting to you. Let me find favor in your sight, your majesty the king!”
speaker: Narrator

text: Later on, as King David approached Bahurim, Gera’s son Shimei, who was related to the family of Saul’s household, went out to meet David, cursing continually as he approached.
speaker: Narrator

text: He threw rocks at David and all of David’s staff who were accompanying him, while all the rest of the entourage, including all of David’s security detail, were close by him.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Get out of here! Get out!” Shimei yelled as he cursed. “You murderer! You who think you’re above the law!
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord has repaid you personally for murdering the entire dynasty of Saul, whose place you’ve taken to reign! And the Lord has given the kingdom into your son Absalom’s control. Now look! Your own evil has caught up with you, because you’re guilty of murder!”
speaker: Narrator

text: At this point, Zeruiah’s son Abishai asked the king, “Why should this dead dog be cursing your majesty the king? May I have permission to go over and cut off his head?”
speaker: Narrator

text: But the king responded, “What do I have in common with you sons of Zeruiah? If he continues to curse—and if the Lord has told him, ‘Curse David!’—then who are you to be demanding to know ‘Why have you done this?’”
speaker: Narrator

text: So David ordered Abishai and all of his staff: “Look! My own son wants to kill me! How much more now is this descendant of Benjamin? Leave him alone and let him go on cursing, because the Lord has ordered him to do this.
speaker: Narrator

text: Perhaps the Lord will take note of my troubles and return good to me instead of curses today!”
speaker: Narrator

text: So David and his entourage went on their way, and Shimei walked along the hillside with him, cursing, throwing rocks, and tossing dirt at David as they went along.
speaker: Narrator

text: Eventually, the king and his entourage arrived exhausted at their destination, and David refreshed himself there.
speaker: Narrator

text: Right about then, Absalom and his entourage from the people of Israel entered Jerusalem, accompanied by Ahithophel.
speaker: Narrator

text: When David’s friend Hushai the Archite approached Absalom, Hushai greeted Absalom, “Long live the king! Long live the king!”
speaker: Narrator

text: But Absalom asked Hushai, “So this is how you demonstrate your loyalty to your closest friends? Why didn’t you leave with your friend?”
speaker: Narrator

text: Hushai replied, “No! On the contrary, whomever the Lord, this group, and all the men of Israel choose is where I’ll be, and I’ll remain with him!
speaker: Narrator

text: Besides, who else should I be serving? Why not the son? The same way I served your father, I’ll serve you.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Absalom asked Ahithophel, “What’s your advice? What should we do?”
speaker: Narrator

text: Ahithophel responded, “Go inside and have sex with your father’s mistresses, whom he left to keep the palace in order. Then everyone in Israel will hear how your father has come to hate you and everyone who has joined you will be emboldened to act.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So they erected a tent for Absalom on the palace roof and Absalom went in and had sex with his father’s mistresses right in front of all Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now Ahithophel’s advice that he provided at that time was being compared to one who inquired of God, so highly regarded was Ahithophel’s counsel by both David and Absalom.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Give me 12,000 men! I’ll leave tonight and pursue David,” Ahithophel advised Absalom.
speaker: Narrator

text: “I’ll catch him while he is still tired and weak. I’ll frighten him so all his people with him desert him. But I’ll only kill the king.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then I’ll bring everybody else back to you. When the man you’re looking for is dead, all the rest of the people will return quietly.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Even though this plan seemed like a good idea to Absalom and to all of the elders of Israel,
speaker: Narrator

text: Absalom replied, “Call in Hushai the Archite so I can hear what he has to say, too!”
speaker: Narrator

text: When Hushai approached Absalom, Absalom asked him, “Here’s what Ahithophel had to advise. Should we do what he says? Or if not, say so!”
speaker: Narrator

text: “Ahithophel’s advice is not best at this time,” Hushai suggested to Absalom.
speaker: Narrator

text: “You know how strong your father and his men are. They’re as mad as a bear robbed of her cubs! Furthermore, your father is a skilled warrior. He won’t stay with his army at night.
speaker: Narrator

text: Look! He’s probably already hiding in a cave or someplace like that. If the first attack fails, people will hear about it and think, ‘Absalom’s army is losing!’
speaker: Narrator

text: Then even men who would otherwise be as brave as lions will be scared, because every Israeli knows your father is a mighty man, and they know his men are valiant!
speaker: Narrator

text: So here’s my advice: Muster everybody from one end of the country to the other! You’ll have an army in number like the sand on the seashore! Then you’ll go into battle!
speaker: Narrator

text: We’ll go find David wherever he’s hiding. We’ll fall on him like dew on the ground! We’ll kill him and all of his men, and we won’t leave even one man alive!
speaker: Narrator

text: If he escapes into a city, we’ll bring ropes to that city and tear it down! We won’t leave a single stone left in the valley!”
speaker: Narrator

text:
Absalom and all of the Israelis replied, “The advice of Hushai the Archite is better than Ahithophel’s!”
But the Lord had planned to circumvent the sound advice of Ahithophel so the Lord could bring Absalom to destruction.
speaker: Narrator

text: So Hushai told Zadok and Abiathar, the priests, what Ahithophel had suggested to Absalom and the elders of Israel. He also reported what he himself had proposed. Hushai said,
speaker: Narrator

text: “Quick! Get word to David! Tell him not to spend the night at the crossings that lead to the desert. Instead, he must cross the Jordan River immediately. That way, if he crosses the river, the king and his entourage will survive.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Meanwhile, since they could not risk being seen entering the city, Jonathan and Ahimaaz had been waiting at En-rogel, where a young servant woman was to go to inform them and they would then go brief King David.
speaker: Narrator

text: But a young man observed Jonathan and Ahimaaz and informed Absalom, so they left in a hurry, arrived at the home of a man who lived at Bahurim, and hid inside a well that was in his courtyard.
speaker: Narrator

text: The man’s wife grabbed a sheet, covered the mouth of the well with it, and spread some dried grain over it. As a result, nobody could tell it was a hiding place.
speaker: Narrator

text:
When Absalom’s servants approached the woman of the house, they asked her, “Where are Ahimaaz and Jonathan?”
“They’ve already crossed the brook,” the woman answered. So Absalom’s servants went away in search of Jonathan and Ahimaaz, but they couldn’t find them, so they returned to Jerusalem.
speaker: Narrator

text: A little while later, the men crawled up out of the well and went off to talk to King David. They told David, “Get up! Cross the water quickly, because this is what Ahithophel advised about you…”
speaker: Narrator

text: So David got up and all of his entourage crossed the Jordan River. Everyone had crossed the Jordan River by dawn’s first light.
speaker: Narrator

text: Meanwhile, when Ahithophel observed that his counsel was not being acted upon, he saddled his donkey, got up, and left for his hometown. Leaving behind a set of orders for his household, he hanged himself. After his death he was buried in his father’s tomb.
speaker: Narrator

text: Later, David arrived at Mahanaim. Absalom and all of the Israelis who supported him crossed the Jordan River.
speaker: Narrator

text: Absalom had installed Amasa in place of Joab over the army. (Amasa was the son of a man named Jether the Ishmaelite. His mother was Abigail, a daughter of Nahash and a sister of Zeruiah, Joab’s mother.)
speaker: Narrator

text: Absalom and the Israelis with him camped in the territory of Gilead.
speaker: Narrator

text: When David arrived at Mahanaim, Shobi (Nahash’s son from the Ammonite town of Rabbah), Makir (Ammiel’s son from Lo-debar), and Barzillai (from Rogelim in Gilead) were already there.
speaker: Narrator

text: They brought along bedding, bowls, clay basins, wheat, barley, flour, roasted grains, beans, peas,
speaker: Narrator

text: honey, cheeses, sheep, and cheese made from cow’s milk for David and his entourage because they had been reasoning, “The people are hungry, tired, and thirsty there in the wilderness.”
speaker: Narrator

text: David mustered his forces and appointed officers in charge of regiments and companies.
speaker: Narrator

text: Dividing his forces into three groups, he set Joab as commander of one third of his army, Zeruiah’s son Abishai, Joab’s brother, as commander of another third, and Ittai from Gath as commander of another third. The king informed the army, “I’m going out to battle with you, too.”
speaker: Narrator

text: “No way!” his army responded. “If we have to retreat from the battle, Absalom’s men won’t care about us. Even if half of us die, they won’t care about us. But you are worth 10,000 of us. The best thing you can do for us is to remain in the city.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So David responded, “I’ll do what you think best.” Then he stood alongside the city gate as the army went out in battle array by hundreds and thousands.
speaker: Narrator

text: As they were going out, the king ordered Joab, Abishai, and Ittai, “Treat young Absalom gently for my sake.” Everyone heard what the king had ordered his commanders about Absalom.
speaker: Narrator

text: David’s army left for the battlefield to fight Absalom and his Israeli followers, and they also fought in the Ephraim forest,
speaker: Narrator

text: where David’s army of servants defeated the Israelis. Many died that day—20,000 men.
speaker: Narrator

text: The battle spread throughout the entire countryside, and the forest claimed more casualties that day than did the sword fighting.
speaker: Narrator

text: Absalom happened to run into David’s soldiers. While Absalom was trying to get away on his mule, it ran under the thick branches of a giant oak tree, and Absalom’s head got caught in the tree! As his mule ran out from under him, Absalom was left hanging above the ground.
speaker: Narrator

text: When one of the soldiers saw what had happened, he told Joab, “I saw Absalom stuck in an oak tree!”
speaker: Narrator

text: Joab asked the man who was reporting to him, “What! You saw him? Why didn’t you kill him right then and there? I would’ve given you ten pieces of silver and a warrior’s sash!”
speaker: Narrator

text: But the soldier replied to Joab, “I wouldn’t have touched the king’s son even if you dropped 1,000 pieces of silver right into my hands, because we heard the king command you, Abishai, and Ittai, ‘Watch how you treat the young man Absalom!’
speaker: Narrator

text: If I had taken his life, the king would have uncovered everything about it, and you would never have protected me!”
speaker: Narrator

text: “There’s no reason to wait for you!” Joab retorted. Then he took three spears in his hand and stabbed Absalom in the heart while he was still alive, dangling from the branches of the oak tree.
speaker: Narrator

text: Ten young men who served as Joab’s personal assistants then surrounded Absalom, striking him repeatedly and killing him.
speaker: Narrator

text: At this, Joab sounded his battle trumpet and his troops stopped pursuing the other Israelis.
speaker: Narrator

text: Meanwhile, Joab’s army grabbed Absalom’s body, tossed it into a large pit in the forest, and filled it up with a huge pile of rocks. Then the Israelis ran away back to their homes.
speaker: Narrator

text: While Absalom had been living, he had erected a pillar as a monument to himself in King’s Valley because he had been telling himself, “I don’t have a son to carry on my family name.” So he named the pillar after himself—it’s called Absalom’s Monument even today.
speaker: Narrator

text: Zadok’s son Ahimaaz told Joab, “Let me run over to King David and take him the news. I’ll mention that the Lord has delivered him from his enemies.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But Joab answered Ahimaaz, “You’re not the man to deliver news today. Do it any other time, but not today, because the king’s son is dead.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Joab ordered a man from Ethiopia, “Go tell the king what you’ve seen.” So the Ethiopian saluted Joab and then ran to tell David.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Please,” Zadok’s son Ahimaaz continued, “No matter what happens, let me follow the Ethiopian!”
Joab asked him, “Why this request to run, my son? There’s no reward in it for you.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
“No matter what, I’m running,” Ahimaaz replied.
So Joab told Ahimaaz, “Run!” And Ahimaaz ran, taking the Jordan Valley road, passing the Ethiopian.
speaker: Narrator

text: Meanwhile, David was sitting between the inner and outer gates of the city. The watchman was up on the roof of the gateway near the walls, looking around, and there was a man running by himself!
speaker: Narrator

text:
So the watchman called out his news to the king.
The king responded, “If he’s alone, he’s bringing some news to report.” As the man continued to draw near and approach the palace,
speaker: Narrator

text:
the watchman observed another man running. So he called out to the gatekeeper, “There’s another man running by himself!”
The king replied, “He’s also bringing some news to report!”
speaker: Narrator

text:
Then the watchman observed, “It looks to me that the runner out in front is running like Zadok’s son Ahimaaz!”
The king replied, “This is a good man bearing good news!”
speaker: Narrator

text: “Everything’s fine!” Ahimaaz announced to the king. He bowed low with his face to the ground before the king and said, “Praise be to the Lord your God! He has handed over the men who rebelled against your majesty the king.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Are things fine with respect to the young man Absalom?” the king asked.
Ahimaaz answered, “I saw a lot of confusion about the time Joab was getting ready to send the king’s courier and me, your servant, but I’m not sure what was going on.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The king replied, “Stand here at attention and wait.” So he stepped to the side and stood there waiting.
speaker: Narrator

text: Just then the Ethiopian arrived. He reported, “Good news, your majesty the king! The Lord has delivered you from the control of everyone who rebelled against you!”
speaker: Narrator

text:
The king asked the Ethiopian, “Is the young man safe?”
The Ethiopian answered, “May the enemies of your majesty the king—including everyone who rebels and tries to harm you—become like that young man….”
speaker: Narrator

text: Deeply shaken, the king went up to the chamber overlooking the city gate, weeping bitterly and crying out as he went along, “My son Absalom! My son! My son Absalom! I wish I had died instead of you, Absalom my son, my son!”
speaker: Narrator

text: Someone informed Joab, “The king is weeping bitterly, mourning for Absalom.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The victory had become an occasion for the army to mourn, because on that very day the troops heard the announcement, “The king is grieving for his son!”
speaker: Narrator

text: So men snuck into the city that day like men do who are ashamed after they’ve run away from a battle.
speaker: Narrator

text: Meanwhile, the king veiled his face and kept on crying loudly, “My son Absalom! Absalom my son, my son!”
speaker: Narrator

text: Joab went up to the palace and rebuked the king: “Today you’ve humiliated your entire army who just saved your life, the lives of your sons and daughters, and the lives of your wives and mistresses!
speaker: Narrator

text: You love those who hate you and hate those who love you! You’ve made it abundantly clear today that your officers and the men under them mean nothing to you! I’ve learned today that you would rather have Absalom alive today and all the rest of us dead!
speaker: Narrator

text: Now get up and restore the morale of your army. I swear by the Lord that if you don’t get out there, you won’t have a single man left in your army by nightfall! You’ll be in more trouble today than all the disasters you’ve been through from your boyhood until now!”
speaker: Narrator

text:
So the king got up and took his seat in the gateway. When the army was informed, “The king is sitting in the gateway!” they all gathered together in his presence.
Meanwhile, the Israelis had run away back to their own homes.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Throughout the tribes of Israel, everyone was quarreling with one another:
“The king delivered us from the domination of our enemies….”
“He’s the one who rescued us from Philistine control….”
“Now he’s fleeing the country because of Absalom…!”
speaker: Narrator

text:
“The very same Absalom we anointed to rule just died in battle…!”
“Now then, why remain silent about bringing the king back…?”
speaker: Narrator

text: So King David sent this message to Zadok and Abiathar, the priests: “Ask the elders of Judah, ‘Why are you the last to bring the king back to his palace, considering that what’s being reported throughout all of Israel has come to the king at his palace?
speaker: Narrator

text: You’re my relatives! You’re my own flesh and blood! So why are you the last to bring back the king?’
speaker: Narrator

text: Then ask Amasa, ‘Aren’t you my own flesh and blood? So may God deal with me, no matter how severely, if from this day forward you don’t take Joab’s place as commander of my army.’
speaker: Narrator

text: By doing things like this, he persuaded all the men of Judah to unite in support of him. They sent the king this message: “Come on back, you and all of your army!”
speaker: Narrator

text:
So the king returned to Israel as far as the Jordan River.
The men of Judah went out as far as Gilgal to greet the king and escort him across the Jordan River
speaker: Narrator

text: while Gera’s son Shimei, a descendant of Benjamin from Bahurim, accompanied them to meet King David.
speaker: Narrator

text: Ziba, the steward in charge of Saul’s household, and 1,000 descendants of Benjamin accompanied him, along with Ziba’s fifteen sons and 20 servants. They rushed toward the Jordan River ahead of the king
speaker: Narrator

text:
and forded it to assist the king at the crossing so he could do whatever he wished.
Just as the king was about to ford the Jordan River, Gera’s son Shimei fell down in front of the king
speaker: Narrator

text: and addressed him, “May your majesty not hold me guilty. Don’t remember how your servant did wrong the day your majesty the king left Jerusalem. May the king not let it burden his heart,
speaker: Narrator

text: because your servant knows that I have sinned, but today I have come here as the first one from the entire house of Joseph to meet your majesty the king.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But Zeruiah’s son Abishai asked, “Why shouldn’t Shimei be put to death for this? After all, he cursed the Lord’s anointed!”
speaker: Narrator

text: David replied, “What do you sons of Zeruiah have in common with me? You’ve become my enemies today! Should anyone be executed in Israel today? Don’t you know that I’ve been reinstated as king over Israel today?”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the king addressed Shimei, “You won’t die!” affirming his promise with an oath.
speaker: Narrator

text: Meanwhile, Saul’s grandson Mephibosheth also went out to greet the king. He had not taken care of his feet, trimmed his mustache, or washed his clothes from the day the king left until the day he returned safely.
speaker: Narrator

text: When he arrived from Jerusalem to greet the king, the king asked him, “So why didn’t you come with me, Mephibosheth?”
speaker: Narrator

text: He replied, “Well, your majesty, since your servant is lame, I told myself, ‘I’ll have my donkey saddled and I’ll ride on it so I can leave with the king.’ But my servant Ziba deceived me
speaker: Narrator

text: by slandering your servant to your majesty. But your majesty the king is like an angel from God: so do what you think is best.
speaker: Narrator

text: Everyone from my grandfather’s household deserved nothing but death from your majesty the king, but you provided a place for your servant among those who have been eating from your table. So what right do I have to ask for anything more from the king?”
speaker: Narrator

text: In response, the king told him, “What’s the point of us talking anymore? My decision is that you and Ziba divide the fields.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But Mephibosheth told the king, “Let him take all of it, now that your majesty the king has returned safely to his palace.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Barzillai the Gileadite also had come down from Rogelim to cross the Jordan River with the king and to see him on his way from there.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now Barzillai was a very old man at the age of 80 years. A very wealthy man, Barzillai had provided for king David during his sojourn in Mahanaim.
speaker: Narrator

text: So the king invited Barzillai, “Cross the Jordan River with me, live with me in Jerusalem, and I’ll provide for you there.”
speaker: Narrator

text: “How many more years do I have to live,” Barzillai replied to the king, “that I should move to Jerusalem with the king?
speaker: Narrator

text: I’m now 80 years old! I can hardly tell the difference between what tastes good or bad! I can’t tell what I eat or drink! I can’t hear the voice of men and women when they sing! So why should your servant be an added burden to your majesty the king?
speaker: Narrator

text: Your servant will cross the Jordan River with the king for a short distance, but why should the king offer me this reward?
speaker: Narrator

text: Please let your servant return so I can die in my own home town near the grave of my father and mother. Meanwhile, here is your servant Chimham! Let him accompany your majesty the king. Please do for him whatever seems best to you.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So the king answered, “Chimham will accompany me, and I’ll do for him whatever seems best to you! I’ll do anything for you that you want!”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then all the people crossed the Jordan River, followed by the king. The king embraced Barzillai, blessed him, and then Barzillai returned to his home.
speaker: Narrator

text: As the king crossed over the Jordan River to Gilgal, Chimham accompanied him, as did all the troops of Judah and half the troops of Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: Not long afterward, all the men of Israel started coming to the king, complaining to him, “Why did our relatives in Judah’s army sneak you away, taking the king and his household over the Jordan River, along with David’s army?”
speaker: Narrator

text: Everybody from Judah shouted to the men from Israel, “We did this because the king is closely related to us. So why are you angry about this? Have we lived off the king’s expense? Have we appropriated anything for ourselves?”
speaker: Narrator

text: But the men from Israel answered the men from Judah: “We represent ten of the tribes of Israel! So we have more right to David than you do! Why haven’t you taken us seriously? Weren’t we the first to talk about bringing back our king?” But what the people of Judah had to say was harsher than what the people of Israel were saying.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Right about then, Bichri’s son Sheba, an ungodly man from the tribe of Benjamin, sounded a battle trumpet and announced:
We’ve never been a part of David!
    We’ll never gain anything from Jesse’s son!
        It’s every man to his tent, Israel!
speaker: Narrator

text: So all of the other Israeli soldiers abandoned David to follow Bichri’s son Sheba, while the army of Judah remained with the king all the way from the Jordan River to Jerusalem.
speaker: Narrator

text: When David arrived at his palace in Jerusalem, the king took the ten mistresses whom he had left behind to keep the palace in order and placed them in a separate house, providing for them under the care of a protective guard. He never visited them again, so they were under care until they died, living as if their husbands had died.
speaker: Narrator

text: Meanwhile, David ordered Amasa, “Muster the army of Judah here within three days, and be here yourself!”
speaker: Narrator

text: But when Amasa went out to muster the army of Judah, he delayed to act within the time allotted to him.
speaker: Narrator

text: So David told Abishai, “Now Bichri’s son Sheba is about to do more damage than did Absalom. So take my personal guards and go after them. Otherwise, he’ll run to one of the fortified cities and escape from us.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Joab’s men, the special forces and mercenaries, and all of David’s elite forces left Jerusalem in pursuit of Bichri’s son Sheba.
speaker: Narrator

text: When they arrived at the great stone that is in Gibeon, Amasa came out to meet them. Joab was dressed in a soldier’s uniform, over which was a belt that fastened a sword sheath to his thigh. As he walked forward, the sword was exposed.
speaker: Narrator

text: Joab asked Amasa, “Is everything going well with you, my brother?” As Joab took Amasa by his beard to greet him,
speaker: Narrator

text: Amasa did not notice the sword that Joab was holding in his hand. Joab stabbed him in the abdomen, spilling his intestines to the ground in a single stroke and killing him. After this, Joab and his brother pursued Bichri’s son Sheba.
speaker: Narrator

text: One of Joab’s soldiers stood by Amasa while he lay dying and announced, “Whoever is in favor of Joab and David, let him follow Joab.”
speaker: Narrator

text: While Amasa lay wallowing in his blood in the middle of the highway, everybody who passed by was stopping to stare at him, so when the soldier saw that all of the army was stopping, he carried Amasa off the highway into a nearby field and covered him with a garment.
speaker: Narrator

text: After Amasa had been removed from the highway, the rest of the army followed Joab in pursuit of Bichri’s son Sheba.
speaker: Narrator

text: Meanwhile, Sheba traveled throughout the tribes of Israel in the direction of Abel and Beth-maacah, and all of the descendants of Beri gathered together and followed him inside.
speaker: Narrator

text: All of the men who had accompanied Joab arrived and besieged Sheba in Abel of Beth-maacah. They threw up a siege ramp against the city rampart and began to batter the wall to demolish it.
speaker: Narrator

text: Just then a wise woman called out from the city. “Attention!” she said, “Go tell Joab ‘Come here! I want to talk to you!’”
speaker: Narrator

text:

“I am,” he answered.
So she told him, “Listen to what your servant has to say!”
“I’m listening,” he replied.
speaker: Narrator

text: So she said, “In days past, people used to settle a dispute by saying ‘Let’s ask for advice at Abel!’
speaker: Narrator

text: I’m one of the peaceful and faithful citizens of Israel. You’re trying to destroy a city that’s a mother in Israel. Why are you devouring the heritage of the Lord?”
speaker: Narrator

text: But Joab replied, “No way! No way! I’m not here to devour or destroy!
speaker: Narrator

text:
That’s a lie! But there is a man from the Ephraim hill country—he’s known as Bichri’s son Sheba—who has rebelled against King David. Turn him over and I’ll withdraw from the city!”

speaker: Narrator

text: Then the woman wisely went back to her people. They cut off the head of Bichri’s son Sheba and threw it out to Joab, so Joab sounded his battle trumpet and they withdrew from the city. Everybody went back home and Joab returned to the king at Jerusalem.
speaker: Narrator

speaker: Narrator

text: One time there was a famine during David’s reign that went on for three straight years. David sought the Lord, who said, “Saul and his household are guilty because he executed the Gibeonites.”
speaker: Narrator

speaker: Narrator

text: So David asked the Gibeonites, “What am I to do for you? How am I to make atonement so that you will bless the Lord’s heritage?”
speaker: Narrator

text:

speaker: Narrator

text: They told the king, “The man who consumed us, who planned our destruction—intending to leave us with nothing in the territory of Israel—
speaker: Narrator

text:
is to have seven of his sons turned over to us. We will hang them in the presence of the Lord at Gibeah, which belonged to Saul, whom the Lord chose.”

speaker: Narrator

speaker: Narrator

text: Instead, the king arrested Aiah’s daughter Rizpah’s two sons Armoni and Mephibosheth, whom she had borne to Saul, and the five sons of Saul’s daughter Merab, whom she had borne to Barzillai the Meholathite’s son Adriel.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then he turned them over to the custody of the Gibeonites, who hanged them on the mountain in the presence of the Lord. All seven of them died at the same time. They were executed during the first days of harvest, just as the barley began to be gathered in.

speaker: Narrator

text: When David was informed what Rizpah, the daughter of Saul’s mistress had done,
speaker: Narrator

speaker: Narrator

text: He brought the bones of Saul and his son Jonathan from there along with the bones of those who had been hanged,
speaker: Narrator

speaker: Narrator

speaker: Narrator

speaker: Narrator

speaker: Narrator

text: David composed the words of this song to the Lord the very day the Lord delivered him from the domination of all of his enemies, including from Saul’s hands.
speaker: Narrator

text:
This is what he said:
Lord, you are my stone stronghold
    and my fortified place;
        you are continuously delivering me.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He is my God,
    my strong stone—
        in him I will find my refuge—
my shield,
    the strength of my salvation,
        my high tower,
my way of escape,
    and the one who is saving me.
        You will save me from violence.
speaker: Narrator

text:
As I am praising him,
    I will call out to the Lord,
        and I will be saved from my enemies.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Because deadly breakers engulfed me,
    while torrents of abuse from the ungodly overwhelmed me.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Binding ropes from Sheol entangled me
    while lethal snares hindered me.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I cried out to the Lord in the middle of my troubles;
    I cried out to my God.
He listened to my voice from his sanctuary,
    and my call for help was heard.
speaker: Narrator

text:

    The foundations of heaven reeled and quaked

speaker: Narrator

text:
Smoke poured out of his nostrils,

text:
He deformed heaven itself as he descended.
    Thick darkness enveloped his feet.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He rode on a cherub and flew,
    soaring on the wings of the wind!
speaker: Narrator

text:
The darkness around him was his canopies—
    amassed water was his overhanging clouds!
speaker: Narrator

text:
From the shining light that was his presence
    coals of fire blazed into flame!
speaker: Narrator

text:
The Lord roared from heaven!
    The Most High let his voice be heard!
speaker: Narrator

text:
He launched his arrows and scattered them—
    his lightning routed them.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The currents of the sea were revealed
    and the foundations of the world were exposed
at the rebuke of the Lord
    and at the blazing breath from his nostrils!
speaker: Narrator

text:
He sent for me from on high!
    He grabbed hold of me,
        drawing me out of deep water.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

They confronted me when I was in trouble,

speaker: Narrator

text:
He brought me to a wide open area,
    rescuing me because he was pleased with me!
speaker: Narrator

text:

    rewarding me according to the degree of my innocence,
speaker: Narrator

text:
because I have kept the Lord’s way—

speaker: Narrator

text:
and because all of his decrees remain in my thoughts,

speaker: Narrator

text:
I have been innocent before him,

speaker: Narrator

text:
The Lord has repaid me according to my righteousness,

speaker: Narrator

text:
In the company of the gracious

In the company of the blamelessly valiant

speaker: Narrator

text:
In the company of the pure
    you demonstrate your purity.
In the company of the perverted
    you will appear to be perverse.
speaker: Narrator

text:
You save the nation who is humble
    but your eyes watch the proud,
        to bring them down.
speaker: Narrator

text:
For you are my lamp, Lord,
    the Lord who illuminates my darkness.
speaker: Narrator

text:
By you I devastate armies,
    by my God I scale walls.
speaker: Narrator

text:
This God! His way is perfect!
    What the Lord declares proves true.
        He shields everyone who flees for protection to him!
speaker: Narrator

text:
For who is God apart from the Lord?
    And who is a Rock, apart from our God?
speaker: Narrator

text:
This God is my strong place of valor!
    He has made my life blameless.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He has made my feet like those of a deer,
    setting me secure on his high places!
speaker: Narrator

text:
He has trained my hands for battle readiness—
    I can bend a bow made out of bronze.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He has equipped me with the shield that is your salvation,

speaker: Narrator

text:
You’ve made room beneath me for my footsteps,

speaker: Narrator

text:

text:
I devoured them,

until they could not get up again.

speaker: Narrator

text:

speaker: Narrator

text:
You made my enemies turn and run—

speaker: Narrator

text:
They looked around, but there was no one to save them—

speaker: Narrator

text:
I pulverized them to powder,
    like the dust of the earth;
I crushed them,
    stomping on them like mud on a street.
speaker: Narrator

text:
You delivered me from civil war among my own people.
    You preserved me as head of the nations.
        People whom I had never known served me!
speaker: Narrator

text:
Foreigners came cringing to me;
    they obeyed as soon as they heard me.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Foreigners lost their courage,
    coming trembling from their strongholds.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The Lord lives!
    Blessed be my Rock,
and may my God be exalted,
    the Rock who is my salvation!
speaker: Narrator

text:
The God who keeps on avenging me,
    subjugating people beneath me,
speaker: Narrator

text:
delivering me from my enemies.

    delivering me from violent men.
speaker: Narrator

Because of all of this I will praise you among the nations, Lord,

speaker: Narrator

Great is the salvation he brings to his king,

speaker: Narrator

This was David’s last composition:
The oracle of David, son of Jesse,
    an oracle by the valiant one who was exalted—
anointed by the God of Jacob,
    the contented psalm writer of Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The Spirit of the Lord speaks within me;
    his word is on my tongue!
speaker: Narrator

text:
The God of Israel has spoken;
    the Rock of Israel has talked to me.
“When one is governing men justly,

He is like dawn’s first light,
    like bright sun blazing on a cloudless morning,

Is not my dynasty like this with God?
    Has he not made an eternal covenant with me,

speaker: Narrator

But ungodly men are like thorns that are discarded
