text: Here’s a list of the names of David’s special forces: Josheb-basshebeth the Tahkemonite was head of the Three; he was nicknamed Adino the Eznite because he killed 800 men in a single battle engagement.
speaker: Narrator

text: Next was Dodai the Ahohite’s son Eleazar. Eleazar, who also was one of the Three, was with David when they challenged the Philistines. When the Philistines had assembled in battle array, the Israeli army retreated,
speaker: Narrator

text: but Eleazar remained standing right where he was and fought so hard against the Philistines that he became exhausted—he couldn’t even let go of his sword! The Lord magnificently delivered them that day. After Eleazar had won the battle, the other soldiers returned, but only to strip the weapons and armor from the dead.
speaker: Narrator

text: Next was Shammah, Agee the Hararite’s son. One time the Philistines assembled to fight in a field where lentils had been growing. Israel’s army retreated from the Philistines,
speaker: Narrator

text: but Shammah stood his ground in the middle of the field, defended it, and killed the Philistines. And the Lord brought about a great victory.
speaker: Narrator

text: One day while the Philistine army was camping in the valley of giants, three of the 30 leaders joined David at the cave of Adullam.
speaker: Narrator

text: David was living in that stronghold at the time, while a Philistine garrison was then at Bethlehem.
speaker: Narrator

text: David expressed his longing, “Oh, how I wish someone would get me a drink of water from the Bethlehem well that’s by the city gate!”
speaker: Narrator

text: So the Three elite warriors broke through the Philistine ranks, drew some water from the Bethlehem well that was next to the city gate, and brought it back to David. But he refused to drink it. Instead, he poured it out in the Lord’s presence,
speaker: Narrator

text: and said, “The Lord forbid that I drink this—this is the blood of men who endangered their own lives!” The Three elite warriors did these things.
speaker: Narrator

text: Zeruiah’s son Abishai, Joab’s brother, was the lieutenant in charge of the platoons. He used his spear to fight and kill 300 men, gaining a reputation distinct from the Three.
speaker: Narrator

text: He was more well-known than the Three, and became their commander, but he never measured up to the Three.
speaker: Narrator

text: Jehoiada’s son Benaiah, who was a valiant man, accomplished great things. He was from Kabzeel. He killed two men named Ariel from Moab and then he also went down into a pit and struck down a lion during a snow storm one day.
speaker: Narrator

text: He also killed a soldier from Egypt. Of handsome appearance, the Egyptian carried a spear, but Benaiah attacked him with a staff, snatched the spear out of the Egyptian’s hand and killed him with his own spear.
speaker: Narrator

text: Benaiah did things like this and gained a reputation comparable to the Three warriors.
speaker: Narrator

text: He was well known among the platoons, but he didn’t measure up to the Three. David placed him in charge of his security detail.
speaker: Narrator

text: Among the Thirty were Joab’s brother Asahel, Dodo’s son Elhanan of Bethlehem,
speaker: Narrator

text: Shammah from Harod; Elika from Harod,
speaker: Narrator

text: Helez the Paltite, Ikkesh’s son Ira from Tekoa,
speaker: Narrator

text: Abiezer from Anathoth, Mebunnai the Hushathite,
speaker: Narrator

text: Zalmon the Ahohite, Maharai of Netophah,
speaker: Narrator

text: Baanah’s son Heleb from Netophah, Ribai’s son Ittai from Gibeah of the descendants of Benjamin,
speaker: Narrator

text: Benaiah from Pirathon, Hiddai from the Gaash creeks area,
speaker: Narrator

text: Abi-albon the Arbathite, Azmaveth from Bahurim,
speaker: Narrator

text: Eliahba from Shaalbon, Jashen’s sons,
speaker: Narrator

text: Shammah’s son from Harar, Sharar the Hararite’s son Ahiam,
speaker: Narrator

text: Ahasbai the Maacathite’s son Eliphelet, Ahithophel the Gilonite’s son Eliam,
speaker: Narrator

text: Hezro from Carmel, Paarai the Arbite,
speaker: Narrator

text: Nathan’s son Igal from Zobah, Bani the Gadite,
speaker: Narrator

text: Zelek the Ammonite, Naharai from Beeroth (the armor-bearer for Zeruiah’s son Joab),
speaker: Narrator

text: Ira the Ithrite, Gareb the Ithrite,
speaker: Narrator

text: and Uriah the Hittite—for a total of 37.
speaker: Narrator

text: Later, God’s anger blazed forth against Israel, so he incited David to move against them by telling him, “Go take a census of Israel and Judah.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So the king ordered Joab, commander of the special forces, who was with him, “Go throughout the tribes of Israel from Dan to Beer-sheba and take a census of the people so I can be made aware of the total number.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But Joab replied, “May the Lord your God increase the population of the people a hundredfold while your majesty the king is still alive to see it happen! But why does your majesty the king want to do this?”
speaker: Narrator

text: But the king’s order overruled Joab and the commanders of the special forces, so Joab and the commanders of the special forces left David’s presence to take a census of the people of Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: They crossed the Jordan River, encamped at Aroer south of the town that is located in the river valley, proceeding through Gad and then on toward Jazer.
speaker: Narrator

text: They went on to Gilead and the territory of Tahtim-hodshi, then on toward Dan. From Dan they went around to Sidon
speaker: Narrator

text:
and arrived at the fortified city of Tyre and all of the towns of the Hivites and Canaanites.
Eventually they proceeded to Beer-sheba in the Judean Negev.
speaker: Narrator

text: After they had traveled throughout the entire land, they returned to Jerusalem at the end of nine months and 20 days.
speaker: Narrator

text: Joab reported the total number of men to the king. In Israel there were 800,000 men trained for war. In Judah there were 500,000.
speaker: Narrator

text: Later, David’s conscience bothered him after he had numbered the army, so David told the Lord, “I have sinned greatly by what I did. But now I am asking you, please remove the guilt of your servant, since I have acted very foolishly.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Before David arose the next morning, this message from the Lord came to Gad, David’s seer:
speaker: Narrator

text: “Go tell David, ‘This is what the Lord says: “I’m holding three choices out for you: pick one of them for yourself, and I will do it to you.”’”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Gad went to David and asked him, “Shall seven years of famine come to your land, or three months of reversals while you flee from your enemies as they pursue you, or three days of pestilence in your land? Decide right now what I am to answer to the one who sent me.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So David replied to Gad, “This is a very difficult choice for me to make! Let me now please fall into the hand of the Lord, since his mercy is very great, but may I never fall into human hands!”
speaker: Narrator

text: That very morning, the Lord sent a pestilence to Israel until the conclusion of the time designated, and 70,000 men died from Dan to Beer-sheba.
speaker: Narrator

text: As the angel was stretching out his hand to destroy Jerusalem, the Lord was grieved because of the calamity, so he told the angel who was afflicting the people, “Enough! Stay your hand!” So the angel of the Lord remained near the threshing floor that belonged to Araunah the Jebusite.
speaker: Narrator

text: When David saw the angel who had been attacking the people, he told the Lord, “Look, I’m the one who has sinned! I did the evil. These are only sheep! What did they do? Please, let your hand fall on me and on my household!”
speaker: Narrator

text: That very day, Gad approached David and told him, “Go up and build an altar to the Lord on the threshing floor that belongs to Araunah the Jebusite.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So David went up, just as Gad had ordered, consistent with the Lord’s command.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Araunah looked down, he saw the king and his staff approaching him. Araunah went out, bowed down before the king with his face on the ground,
speaker: Narrator

text:
and asked him, “Why has your majesty the king come to his servant?”
David replied, “To purchase your threshing floor and to build an altar to the Lord, so the pestilence can be averted from the people.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Araunah responded to David, “May your majesty the king take it and offer whatever pleases him. Here are oxen for a burnt offering, along with the threshing sledges and yokes from the oxen for wood!
speaker: Narrator

text: Your majesty, Araunah gives all of this to the king.” Araunah also told the king, “May the Lord your God be pleased with you!”
speaker: Narrator

text: “No!” the king replied to Araunah. “I will buy them from you at full price. I won’t offer to the Lord my God burnt offerings that cost me nothing.” So David bought the threshing floor and the oxen for 50 silver shekels,
speaker: Narrator

text: built an altar to the Lord there, and presented burnt offerings and peace offerings. So the Lord answered David’s prayers for the land and the pestilence on Israel was averted.
speaker: Narrator
